	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

Queues can be snoozed to enforce politeness (usually just a few seconds),
t=
his is controlled by the delay-factor, max-delay-ms and min-delay-ms
settin=
gs on the Frontier.
 
Queues can also be snoozed if a _retryable error_ occ=
urs (i.e. errors that
may be caused by transient network issues, such as a =
server going down etc.)
This usually results in snoozing a queue for severa=
l minutes 900 seconds (15
min) by default and is controlled by the retry-de=
lay-seconds setting on the
Frontier. The number of retries before it gives =
up is controlled by the
max-retries setting.
 
Hope this helps.
 
- Kris

-=

> I've got another=

> If i understood it correctly everytime=
 a exception
> during the crawl is thrown, the crawler waits for a
> given =
time before he continues the crawl. The
> problem

out 15 minutes or something
> like it, that's ways to long in my eyes... No=
w my
> question is, where the setting for the duration of
> the
> timeout c=
an be found and (hopefully) changed (if
> there
> is a setting for it at al=
l...)
> 
Hmm i just remarked that i was wrong because i had a
queue snoozin=
g but it still continued to crawl (i
guess it just stopped crawling last ti=
me cuz there was
nothing else to do...) but there's still a question
open: =
How is the "sleep time" calculated for a
snoozing queue cuz this time it sn=
oozed for a few
seconds?
